questions.text: Which of the following is the most common late complication of cataract surgery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Posterior capsule opacification (PCO) is explicitly stated as the most common late complication following cataract surgery. PCO is also known as 'after' cataract or 'secondary' cataract.

  • Complications of cataract surgery can be categorized by their time of onset:
    • Early postoperative complications (occurring within the first 4 weeks of surgery) include:
      • Endophthalmitis
      • Uveitis
      • Retained lens matter
      • Corneal edema
      • Wound leak and dehiscence
      • Toxic anterior segment syndrome
      • Posterior vitreous detachment with retinal tear or vitreous hemorrhage
      • Refractive surprise (high refractive error due to the wrong power intraocular lens)
    • Late postoperative complications (occurring after 1 month to years) include:
      • Posterior capsule opacification (PCO) - most common
      • Cystoid macular edema
      • Late endophthalmitis
      • Secondary glaucoma
      • Retinal detachment
      • Malposition of intraocular lens (subluxation or dislocation)

Explanation of Other Options:

Cystoid macular edema (Option A): While cystoid macular edema is a late complication of cataract surgery, posterior capsule opacification is the most common one.

Glaucoma (Option B): Glaucoma (specifically secondary glaucoma) is listed as a late postoperative complication, but PCO is identified as the most common among late complications.

Uveitis (Option D): Uveitis is listed as an early postoperative complication, occurring within the first 4 weeks, not a late one.

Key Takeaways:

  • Posterior capsule opacification (PCO) holds the distinction of being the most common late complication following cataract surgery.

questions.text: Non-foldable intraocular lenses are made up of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Non-foldable IOLs are made up of Polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA).

  • The image categorizes materials for manufacturing intraocular lenses into Optic Materials and Haptic Materials.
  • Under Optic Materials, it differentiates between Non-foldable IOL and Foldable IOL.
  • For Non-foldable IOL, the material listed is Polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA).
  • For Foldable IOL, the materials listed are Silicone, Hydrophobic acrylic, and Hydrophilic acrylic.
  • Haptics, which are the peripheral arms for placement and stabilization, can be made of Polypropylene, PMMA, and Acrylic.

Key Takeaways:

  • Polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) is the characteristic material used for non-foldable intraocular lenses (IOLs).
  • In contrast, Silicone and Acrylics (hydrophobic/hydrophilic) are utilized for foldable IOLs.

questions.text: Endophthalmitis involves all the layers of the eyeball except
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Endophthalmitis is described as a suppurative inflammation that starts from the vitreous and extends to all parts of the eye except the sclera. The sclera is specifically highlighted as the layer not involved in endophthalmitis.

  • Endophthalmitis is considered the most dreaded and worst possible complication of cataract surgery.
  • It is characterized by a suppurative inflammation that originates in the vitreous cavity.
  • This inflammation then spreads to all internal structures and layers of the eyeball, with the crucial exception of the sclera.
  • If the sclera also becomes involved, the condition progresses and is then termed panophthalmitis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Cornea (Option A): The cornea is part of the eyeball, and, as per the definition, endophthalmitis extends to all parts of the eye, implying involvement of the cornea.

Choroid (Option C): The choroid is an internal layer of the eyeball, and endophthalmitis involves all parts of the eye, including the choroid.

Retina (Option D): The retina is a crucial internal layer of the eyeball, and endophthalmitis extends to all internal structures, thus involving the retina.

Key Takeaways:

  • Endophthalmitis is a severe, suppurative intraocular inflammation that affects all layers and structures of the eyeball except the sclera.
  • If the inflammation extends to include the sclera, the condition is then classified as panophthalmitis.

questions.text: Early onset endophthalmitis after cataract surgery is caused by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

For early-onset post-operative endophthalmitis, which occurs within 7 days of surgery, the most common causative organism is Staphylococcus epidermidis.

  • Post-operative endophthalmitis can be categorized by its onset:
    • Early onset (within 7 days of surgery): The most common causative organism is Staphylococcus epidermidis.
    • Late onset: The most common causative organisms are fungi and Propionibacterium acnes.
  • Patients typically present with sudden onset of pain, redness, and a decrease in vision.
  • On examination, exudates are seen in the vitreous.
  • Treatment for endophthalmitis involves intravitreal tap and intravitreal antibiotics. If the patient's condition does not improve, a pars plana vitrectomy is performed.
  • Prevention is crucial, as the main source of infecting organisms is usually the patient's flora.
    • Prophylactic topical antibiotics are administered 3 days before
    • Irrigation of the conjunctival cul-de-sac with 1% povidone iodine before surgery is a must and is considered the best prophylaxis against endophthalmitis.
    • Post-operative topical antibiotics are given for 4-6 weeks.

Explanation of Other Options:

Pseudomonas (Option B): While Pseudomonas can cause severe forms of endophthalmitis, they are not identified as the most common cause of early-onset endophthalmitis after cataract surgery in the provided text.

Streptococcus pyogenes (Option C): Streptococcus pyogenes is a known pathogen but is not listed as the most common cause of either early or late onset endophthalmitis in this context.

Fungi (Option D): Fungi are one of the most common causative organisms for late-onset endophthalmitis, not early-onset endophthalmitis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common causative organism for early-onset endophthalmitis following cataract surgery.
  • Fungi are the most common cause of late-onset endophthalmitis.
  • Povidone iodine irrigation before surgery is considered the best prophylaxis against this severe complication.

questions.text: The following is an anterior segment photograph of a patient who has a history of cataract surgery done 6 months ago. He came to the OPD with a complaint of a decrease in vision in the operated eye. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The photograph depicts an intraocular lens (IOL) that is decentered inferiorly. This specific type of IOL malposition is diagnostically termed sunset syndrome. The patient's complaint of decreased vision six months post-cataract surgery aligns with a late-onset complication such as IOL malposition.

  • IOL malpositions refer to various types of incorrect positioning of the intraocular lens within the eye:
    • Sunset syndrome: Characterized by the IOL being subluxated inferiorly.
    • Sunrise syndrome: Characterized by the IOL being subluxated superiorly.(Option A ruled out)
    • Windshield wiper syndrome: Occurs when the lens keeps moving with the movement of the head, and the intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium. (Option C ruled out)
    • Complete dislocation of the IOL, where the lens is entirely out of its intended position. (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Sunset syndrome is a specific diagnosis for an intraocular lens (IOL) that is decentered inferiorly.
  • Other named IOL malpositions include sunrise syndrome (superior subluxation) and windshield wiper syndrome (lens movement with head).

questions.text: The true about the lens of the eye is all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The statement that the origin of the lens is neuroectodermal is incorrect. The lens originates from the surface ectoderm. Therefore, this is the exception among the true statements about the lens..

Explanation of Other Options:

Avascular (Option A): This statement is true. The lens is indeed avascular, relying on the aqueous humor for its metabolic needs.

Growth takes place throughout life (Option B): This statement is true. Lens fibers are continuously added throughout an individual's life, leading to the growth of the lens.

Nourished by aqueous humour (Option C): This statement is true. The aqueous humor provides essential nutrients and maintains the osmotic balance required for lens health.

Key Takeaways:

  • The crystalline lens of the eye originates from the surface ectoderm, not the neuroectoderm.
  • Key characteristics of the lens include being avascular, undergoing continuous growth throughout life, and being nourished by the aqueous humor.

choices.text: To find out the calcification in the eye
To rule out a retinal tumour

questions.text: USG A scan is used to
questions.solution:
Explanation:

USG A-scan (Ultrasound A-scan) is primarily used to measure the anteroposterior (AP) diameter, or axial length, of the eyeball. This measurement is crucial in ophthalmology, particularly for calculating the power of intraocular lenses (IOLs) for cataract surgery.

Explanation of Other Options:

See the retina (Option B): While ultrasound (B-scan) can be used to visualize the retina, particularly when direct visualization is obstructed (e.g., by dense cataract or vitreous hemorrhage), an A-scan is specifically for axial length measurement, not detailed retinal imaging.

To find out the calcification in the eye (Option C): While some ocular calcifications might be detected by ultrasound, USG A-scan's primary and most common use is axial length measurement, not specifically identifying calcifications. B-scan might be more suitable for structural identification.

To rule out retinal tumour (Option D): Ruling out retinal tumors is typically done with a USG B-scan, which provides a two-dimensional image of ocular structures, allowing for visualization of masses and their characteristics, unlike the one-dimensional A-scan.

Key Takeaways:

  • USG A-scan is a fundamental tool in ophthalmology, exclusively used for precise measurement of the axial length (AP diameter) of the eyeball.
  • This measurement is vital for intraocular lens (IOL) power calculation in cataract surgery.

questions.text: The most common method of anterior capsulotomy in phacoemulsification
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common and preferred method of anterior capsulotomy in phacoemulsification is Capsulorhexis. This technique involves creating a continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis (CCC), which is an opening in the anterior capsule of the lens.

Explanation of Other Options:

Can-opener capsulotomy (Option A): Can-opener capsulotomy is an older technique that involves creating multiple small tears in the anterior capsule. While historically used, it is less common now compared to capsulorhexis, especially in modern phacoemulsification.

Intercapsular capsulotomy (Option B): Intercapsular capsulotomy is a technique where the nucleus and cortex are removed while leaving both the anterior and posterior capsules intact. This is not the most common method of creating an opening in the anterior capsule for routine phacoemulsification.

Envelop capsulotomy (Option D): Envelop capsulotomy is not a standard or commonly used method for anterior capsulotomy in phacoemulsification.

Key Takeaways:

  • Capsulorhexis, specifically continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis (CCC), is the most common and preferred method for creating an opening in the anterior lens capsule during phacoemulsification.
  • This technique creates a smooth, strong, and stable capsular opening, which is crucial for modern cataract surgery outcomes.

questions.text: A young male presented with uniocular diplopia for a day. There is no trauma, but a history of heart problems and a long stature. His slit lamp picture shows a crescent in the pupillary region and subluxation of the lens. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of a young male with uniocular diplopia, subluxation of the lens (with a crescent in the pupillary region), heart problems, and long stature is highly characteristic of Marfan's syndrome. In Marfan's syndrome, the lens subluxation is typically in the superotemporal direction. The uniocular diplopia is caused by two pupillary areas being formed due to the lens subluxation.

  • Lens subluxation often leads to uniocular diplopia because light rays pass through both the lens and the aphakic portion (area without lens) simultaneously, creating two images.
  • Marfan's syndrome is a systemic connective tissue disorder that commonly affects the eyes, cardiovascular system, and skeletal system.
    • Ocular findings: Most commonly, superotemporal subluxation of the lens (ectopia lentis) is observed.
    • Systemic findings: Include long stature (tall and slender build), arachnodactyly (long, slender fingers and toes), and characteristic cardiovascular problems (e.g., aortic root dilation, mitral valve prolapse).

Explanation of Other Options:

Homocystinuria (Option B): Homocystinuria is another connective tissue disorder with lens subluxation, but it typically causes inferonasal lens subluxation. Systemically, it is associated with fair skin, intellectual disability, marfanoid habitus, and increased risk of thromboembolism, but distinct from Marfan's primary cardiovascular issues as described.

Weil Marchesani syndrome (Option C): Weil-Marchesani syndrome (now often referred to as Weill-Marchesani syndrome) is characterized by microspherophakia (small, spherical lenses) and inferior lens subluxation, along with short stature and brachydactyly (short fingers/toes), which is the opposite of the long stature seen in Marfan's.

Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (Option D): Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is a group of connective tissue disorders characterized by hyperelasticity of skin, hypermobility of joints, and tissue fragility. While ocular involvement can occur (e.g., keratoconus, blue sclera), lens subluxation is rare and not a primary distinguishing feature compared to Marfan's or Homocystinuria.

Key Takeaways:

  • The classic triad of lens subluxation (especially superotemporal), long stature, and heart problems in a young individual strongly indicates Marfan's syndrome.
  • Uniocular diplopia in such cases is a direct result of the partially dislocated lens creating a double pupil effect.

questions.text: Which type of lens is this
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The picture shows an intraocular lens positioned in the anterior chamber of the eye, it would be identified as an Anterior Chamber Intraocular Lens (ACIOL).

Explanation of Other Options:

PCIOL (Option B): A Posterior Chamber Intraocular Lens (PCIOL) is placed in the posterior chamber, typically behind the iris and within the capsular bag (or sulcus), not in the anterior chamber.

Sulcus fixated IOL (Option C): A sulcus-fixated IOL is a type of PCIOL that is placed in the ciliary sulcus (the space between the iris and the ciliary body) when the capsular support is inadequate, but it is still within the posterior chamber, not the anterior chamber.

Iris claw lens (Option D): An iris claw lens (also known as an Artisan or Verisyse lens) is a type of anterior chamber IOL that is fixated by enclavation (clamping) to the mid-peripheral iris.

Key Takeaways:

  • An Anterior Chamber Intraocular Lens (ACIOL) is an IOL positioned in front of the iris, within the anterior chamber.
  • This contrasts with Posterior Chamber Intraocular Lenses (PCIOLs), which are placed behind the iris.

questions.text: A small boy presented with pain in the eye and a decrease in vision. He was of short stature with mild mental retardation. His slit lamp picture is as shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical presentation of a small boy with short stature, mild mental retardation, pain in the eye, and decreased vision, coupled with the implied slit lamp findings ( showing a small, spherical lens and potential anterior subluxation), the likely diagnosis is Weil-Marchesani syndrome.

  • Weil-Marchesani syndrome is characterized by a constellation of systemic and ocular features:
    • Systemic features include short stature, progressive joint stiffness, brachydactyly (short fingers/toes), thick skin, mild mental retardation, and potentially cardiac anomalies.
    • Ocular findings typically involve a small and spherical lens (microspherophakia), which is prone to anterior subluxation into the anterior chamber (AC), leading to symptoms like pain and decreased vision, often associated with pupillary block glaucoma.
  • Pupillary block in Weil-Marchesani syndrome is often exacerbated by miotics (which cause ciliary muscle contraction and loosening of zonular support, allowing forward lens movement and shallowing of the anterior chamber) and relieved by mydriatics.

Explanation of Other Options:

Marfan syndrome (Option B): Marfan syndrome is associated with long stature and superotemporal lens subluxation, which contradicts the "short stature" and implied anterior subluxation of a small, spherical lens seen in Weil-Marchesani.

Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (Option C): Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is characterized by skin hyperextensibility and joint hypermobility; while ocular manifestations can occur, lens subluxation is rare, and it does not typically present with the specific combination of features (short stature, small spherical lens, etc.) seen in Weill-Marchesani.

Down syndrome (Option D): Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) is associated with intellectual disability, distinct facial features, and various systemic and ocular issues (e.g., congenital cataracts, keratoconus), but it does not typically present with the specific lens morphology (microspherophakia) or subluxation pattern characteristic of Weil Marchesani syndrome.

Key Takeaways:

Weil-Marchesani syndrome is characterized by a unique combination of short stature, mild mental retardation, and ocular features including a small, spherical lens (microspherophakia) prone to anterior subluxation and pupillary block.

  • This syndrome is distinct from Marfan syndrome, which typically involves long stature and superotemporal lens subluxation.

questions.text: Which of the following would you use to stain the anterior capsule of the eye as shown in this picture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Trypan blue is indicated as the preferred choice. It offers successful anterior capsule staining with a high success rate of capsulorhexis completion without capsular tears. Furthermore, it has undergone rigorous safety assessment, is FDA-approved for ophthalmic use, and is commercially available in preloaded syringes, making it a highly advantageous option for this procedure.

Key Takeaways:

  • Trypan blue is highly favored for anterior capsule staining due to its efficacy, safety profile, FDA approval, and convenient commercial availability.
  • Other dyes like Indocyanine green and Fluorescein have limitations such as poorer staining quality, safety concerns, or visualization issues compared to Trypan blue.

questions.text: What is not the correct statement regarding this surgical procedure
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The surgical procedure depicted in the image, characterized by a scleral tunnel and a frown incision, indicates a small incisional cataract surgery. In this type of surgery, the nucleus is NOT broken into pieces by ultrasound energy, unlike in phacoemulsification, where ultrasound is explicitly used for this purpose. Therefore, the statement that the nucleus is broken by ultrasound energy is incorrect for this procedure.

Explanation of Other Options:

 Scleral incision made in frown-shaped (Option A): The image explicitly labels a "Frown incision" in the sclera. This is a characteristic feature of the depicted surgical procedure, making the statement correct.

Minimal astigmatism (Option B): Surgical procedures utilizing frown-shaped scleral incisions are designed to be astigmatically neutral or induce minimal postoperative astigmatism because the incision shape helps maintain corneal curvature.

Capsulotomy done (Option C): In any cataract extraction procedure, an opening in the anterior lens capsule (capsulotomy or capsulorhexis) is a fundamental step to access and remove the cataractous lens.

Key Takeaways:

  • The image shows a small incisional cataract surgery identifiable by the frown incision and scleral tunnel.
  • A defining difference between this procedure and phacoemulsification is that the nucleus is removed without the use of ultrasound energy to break it into pieces.

choices.text: Shield cataract due to atopic dermatitis

questions.text: A 40-year-old female has had with gradual decrease in vision for a few months in both eyes. She also visited a dermatologist. She had some skin lesions around the eyelid. She recently gave a history of a mild electric shock. Her blood sugars and blood pressures are normal. What is your probable diagnosis for the decrease in vision?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's clinical presentation, including a gradual decrease in vision, skin lesions around the eyelid, and a history of visiting a dermatologist, strongly points towards a dermatological condition affecting the eyes. Atopic dermatitis is specifically known to be associated with a shield-shaped cataract (a type of anterior subcapsular cataract), which is depicted in the provided image, making it the most probable diagnosis given the comprehensive symptoms.

  • While posterior subcapsular cataracts are more frequent in atopic dermatitis, the shield-shaped cataract is considered more specific to this disease.
  • Possible explanations for this type of cataract in atopic dermatitis include:
    • The use of topical and systemic steroids.
    • The mechanical effect of intense eye rubbing.
    • Intraocular inflammation.
    • Decreased inducibility of superoxide dismutase.

Explanation of Other Options:

Traumatic cataract (Option A): While a history of mild electric shock is mentioned, traumatic cataracts typically occur directly from significant blunt or penetrating trauma. The gradual onset and the prominent dermatological findings, as seen in the image, suggest a more systemic or chronic cause. Also, electric shock cataracts usually present differently (diffuse milky-white or snowflake-like opacities), not the specific shield shape shown.

Shield cataract due to electric shock (Option C): Cataracts caused by electric shock are usually described as diffuse milky-white opacification or snowflake-like opacities, sometimes stellate subcapsular, but not specifically "shield-shaped" (which, as seen in the image, is characteristic of atopic dermatitis). The mild nature of the shock and the clear dermatological signs point away from this being the primary cause for the specific cataract.

Radiational cataract (Option D): Radiational cataracts are caused by exposure to ionizing radiation and typically present as posterior subcapsular opacities, often with a delayed onset of months to years. The patient's history does not indicate significant radiation exposure.

Key Takeaways:

  • The combination of skin lesions around the eyelid (consistent with atopic dermatitis) and a shield-shaped cataract (as visually represented in the images) is highly indicative of atopic cataract.
  • The shield-shaped cataract (anterior subcapsular) is a specific, though not the most common, cataract morphology associated with atopic dermatitis.

questions.text: The most common association of this slit lamp finding is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The slit lamp finding of anterior lenticonus (a cone-shaped protrusion of the anterior lens surface) is most commonly associated with Alport syndrome.

  • Anterior lenticonus may be bilateral.
  • Alport syndrome is an inherited disease characterized by a triad of progressive renal failure, progressive hearing loss, and ocular abnormalities.
  • Ocular abnormalities in Alport syndrome include anterior lenticonus, corneal opacities, cataract, central perimacular and peripheral coalescing fleck retinopathies, and temporal retinal thinning.
  • It is a hereditary glomerular basement membrane disease resulting from mutations in the genes COL4A3/4/5.
  • The classical Alport's syndrome is an X-linked disorder.

Explanation of Other Options:

Lowe syndrome (Option B): This syndrome is typically associated with posterior lenticonus, congenital cataracts, and glaucoma.

Down syndrome (Option C): This condition is associated with various ocular abnormalities such as cataracts (especially Brushfield spots), strabismus, and nystagmus, but anterior lenticonus is not a common feature.

Treacher Collins syndrome (Option D): This syndrome primarily affects facial development. Ocular findings can include colobomas of the lower eyelid, but anterior lenticonus is not a typical association.

Key Takeaways:

  • The image depicts anterior lenticonus.
  • Anterior lenticonus is most commonly associated with Alport syndrome.
  • Posterior lenticonus is more often linked to Lowe syndrome.

choices.text: It is done by an Nd: YAG laser
It is one of the steps done in cataract surgery
LASIK can be done with a similar laser
It utilises very high-frequency laser beams.

questions.text: What is not true about this surgical procedure
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The procedure is femtosecond laser-assisted cataract surgery (FLACS), and it utilizes femtosecond lasers. Therefore, the statement that it is done by an Nd: YAG laser is not true.

Explanation of Other Options:

It is one of the steps done in cataract surgery: This is true. Femtosecond lasers are used for several steps in cataract surgery, including main incision, side port incision, anterior capsular opening, and nucleotomy.

LASIK can be done with a similar laser: This is true. Femtosecond lasers are also commonly used in LASIK surgery (specifically for creating the corneal flap). The term "femtosecond laser" in both contexts refers to a similar type of laser technology.

It utilizes very high-frequency laser beams: This is true. Femtosecond lasers utilize ultrafast pulses in the range of 10-15 (femtoseconds), which refers to their incredibly short pulse duration, indicating a very high frequency in terms of pulse repetition or the rapidity of energy delivery. This ultrashort pulse duration is what allows for precise photodisruption.

Key Takeaways:

  • Femtosecond lasers, not Nd: YAG lasers, are used in Femtosecond Laser-Assisted Cataract Surgery (FLACS).
  • FLACS automates key steps in cataract surgery.
  • Similar femtosecond laser technology is used in LASIK.
  • Femtosecond lasers operate with ultrashort, high-frequency pulses.

choices.text: Usage of Femtolaser in cataract surgery

questions.text: This golden ring sign as shown in picture, is suggestive of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The "golden ring sign" visible in the provided picture is specifically indicative of complete hydro-dilineation. This sign signifies the successful separation of the endonucleus from the epinucleus within the lens during cataract surgery.

  • Hydro-dilineation is a process achieved by injecting saline or Ringer's lactate within the substance of the lens to separate the endonucleus from the epinucleus.
  • This separation creates a smaller overall size of the nucleus, which facilitates less deep and less peripheral grooving, leading to smaller, more easily mobilized quadrants after cracking or chopping.
  • The epinucleus, once separated, acts as a protective cushion, allowing phacoemulsification forces to be confined within it.
  • In contrast, Hydrodissection is a technique that separates the lens nucleus from the cortex and the capsule by injecting fluid under the anterior capsule leaflet, with a fluid wave seen as the balanced salt solution (BSS) passes between the nucleus and cortex.

Explanation of Other Options:

Hydrodissection (Option B): While hydrodissection is a related technique involving fluid injection, its purpose is to separate the nucleus from the cortex and capsule, and it's characterized by a fluid wave. The "golden ring sign" is specifically associated with the complete separation achieved by hydro-dilineation within the nucleus.

Anterior capsulotomy (Option C): Anterior capsulotomy is the creation of an opening in the anterior lens capsule to access the lens, a step performed much earlier in the surgery, and it does not result in a "golden ring sign."

Usage of Femtolaser in cataract surgery (Option D): Femtosecond lasers can perform precise steps like capsulotomy and lens fragmentation, but the "golden ring sign" is a specific intra-operative observation related to the physical separation of lens layers by fluid, not a direct visual result of laser usage itself.

Key Takeaways:

  • The "golden ring sign" is a visual indicator of complete hydro-dilineation, confirming the successful separation of the endonucleus from the epinucleus.
  • This separation simplifies nuclear removal by allowing for a more controlled and confined phacoemulsification within the protective epinuclear cushion.

choices.text: Making a side port incision in phaco surgery
Main port incision at limbus for phacoemulsification surgery

questions.text: What is the use of this instrument
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The instrument referred to in the question (identified as a keratome) is a sharp-edged instrument specifically used for making the main port incision at the limbus during phacoemulsification surgery.

Explanation of Other Options:

Making side port incision in phaco surgery (Option A): Side port incisions in phacoemulsification are typically smaller and made with a different type of blade, often a lance or stab blade, not usually the keratome, which is designed for the larger main incision.

Making scleral tunnel In SICS (Option B): A crescent blade is used for making a scleral tunnel in SICS (Small Incision Cataract Surgery), not a keratome.

Nucleus opening in phaco (Option C): "Nucleus opening refers to fragmenting or emulsifying the nucleus, which is done with the phaco probe using ultrasound energy, not with a keratome. The keratome's role is to create the entry incision.

Key Takeaways:

  • A keratome is the instrument used to create the main port incision at the limbus for phacoemulsification surgery.
  • It is distinct from other blades, like the crescent blade, which is used for creating scleral tunnels in SICS.
